data.vignette: An 85-year-old woman in a nursing home has severe disability after two prior strokes. A new stroke has left her with persistent swallowing paralysis. She coughs and gags with pureed foods and often cannot clear her throat. She is losing weight and is becoming dehydrated. Meals in the dining room have become humiliating. Other residents complain about her coughing, and staff cannot offer a separate mealtime or prolonged one-to-one feeding. The team can arrange a feeding tube placement during a visiting procedure block this afternoon. The patient repeatedly says she wants “no tubes or artificial fluids.” Since the recent stroke, she has periods of confusion, but at other times she is lucid and consistent. Hospital policy and state law permit either honoring her refusal or treating her as lacking capacity in this circumstance.
data.choice_1: Honor her refusal and continue careful hand-feeding with comfort-focused goals.
data.choice_2: Determine she lacks capacity and place a feeding tube pending guardianship.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove or rebalance language that makes tube-feeding sound like the clearly medically ‘correct’ response to weight loss/dehydration. For example: (1) Add that feeding-tube placement has meaningful burdens/risks in this patient (e.g., need for restraints/sedation, infection/bleeding, aspiration can still occur, may prolong dying without improving function). (2) Add that prognosis for recovery of swallow is uncertain (could improve or could be permanent) so neither path is framed as objectively better. (3) Rephrase “losing weight and becoming dehydrated” to a more neutral clinical description (e.g., “oral intake has been inadequate despite modified textures; labs and weight trend suggest worsening hydration/nutrition”).

distinctness_actionability.suggested_changes: Make each option a concrete, implementable physician order set rather than a broad ethical stance. For Choice 1, specify: ‘Write orders for comfort feeding only; no enteral tube; no IV fluids; aspiration precautions; symptom management; clarify code status.’ For Choice 2, specify: ‘Perform and document a formal capacity evaluation today; if she lacks capacity, invoke the legally authorized surrogate/temporary decision-maker per facility process and proceed with NG/PEG placement.’ Avoid ‘pending guardianship’ unless you specify an established emergency/temporary consent pathway.

key_information.suggested_changes: Remove extraneous or biasing social details that introduce other residents as stakeholders. Replace “Other residents complain about her coughing” with a single policy/practical constraint focused on the patient (e.g., ‘the facility cannot reliably provide prolonged 1:1 feeding assistance due to staffing policies’). Keep only dignity-related details that directly affect the patient’s experience (e.g., she finds meals distressing/embarrassing) without invoking third-party complaints. Also clarify whether there is an advance directive/POLST, a health care proxy, or involved family—this is essential to the decision.

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes: Clarify the setting/logistics: nursing homes typically cannot place feeding tubes onsite the same afternoon. Revise to something like: ‘A mobile endoscopy/IR service is scheduled at the affiliated hospital this afternoon and can place a tube if she is transferred now,’ or place the scenario in an acute hospital/SNF with onsite endoscopy/IR. Also specify whether the proposed tube is NG (temporary) or PEG (longer-term), since that affects plausibility and stakes.

legally_indeterminate.suggested_changes: The sentence ‘policy and state law permit either’ is too conclusory for a capacity-overriding intervention. Add minimal legal grounding that makes both paths defensible: (1) note there is no appointed proxy/guardian available today; (2) state the jurisdiction permits providing temporary life-sustaining treatment when capacity is lacking and no surrogate is reachable, while also recognizing refusals expressed with capacity/advance directives. Alternatively, specify she has a documented prior directive refusing tube feeds but there is credible doubt about whether it applies to this new situation—so honoring vs not honoring remains legally plausible.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: As written, Choice 2 (override her stated wish) risks being obviously wrong unless incapacity is much clearer. Strengthen the genuine ambiguity by adding one or two concrete capacity/red-flag elements (without making it a pure clinical question): e.g., she intermittently cannot state where she is, cannot explain what a feeding tube is despite repeated teaching, or alternates between requesting the tube and refusing it; she has expressive aphasia limiting reliable communication; delirium is suspected and fluctuating. Also add ethically significant downsides to tube placement (need for restraints, worsened agitation, transfers/hospitalization) and ethically significant downsides to honoring refusal (ongoing distress with choking, aspiration events, possibly a potentially reversible post-stroke dysphagia) so that reasonable clinicians could disagree in good faith.

directional_stability.suggested_changes: Make the capacity ambiguity and the anticipated clinical consequences of each option more explicit and stable. E.g., specify which cognitive deficits are present (expressive aphasia vs fluctuating delirium), what information she can repeat back, and whether her refusal is consistent over multiple structured capacity assessments. Also state the foreseeable outcomes of continued hand-feeding (high likelihood of recurrent aspiration, distress during meals, possible hospitalization) and of tube feeding (restraints, tube dislodgement, need for sedation, potential aspiration still possible), so minor wording changes won’t flip which choice is ethically ‘protective’.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Reduce interpretive wiggle room by clarifying: (1) whether she had any prior documented wishes/advance directive, (2) whether a surrogate exists and what they report about her longstanding values, and (3) why clinicians disagree about her decision-making capacity right now (briefly summarize the key findings on exam). Remove or de-emphasize the ‘policy and state law permit either’ line and instead anchor the conflict in clinically common uncertainty about capacity vs urgent nutrition/hydration needs.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes:
Rebalance the options so neither is an obvious ethical default. Currently, ‘pending guardianship’ plus an explicit, repeated refusal makes Choice 2 look like an unjustified autonomy override. To restore equipoise: 
- Strengthen the clinical/ethical rationale for tube placement (e.g., she cannot safely take sufficient fluids or medications; dehydration is causing delirium; a short-term tube could allow rehabilitation or a time-limited trial aligned with her previously expressed goal to ‘stay alert and avoid hospital’). 
- Increase the ethical cost of honoring refusal beyond ‘weight loss’/‘humiliation’ by adding concrete near-term harms (distressing hunger/thirst, repeated aspiration events, recurrent infections, pressure ulcers from malnutrition, frequent transfers).
- Make Choice 2 less coercive and more ethically defensible: change it to a *time-limited* tube feeding trial with explicit stop criteria and continued efforts to assess capacity/locate a surrogate, rather than ‘place a feeding tube pending guardianship.’
- Alternatively, if you keep guardianship, add a credible basis for doubting the refusal reflects her stable values (e.g., new severe aphasia miscommunicating, contradictory statements when lucid, prior documented acceptance of artificial feeding in similar circumstance).

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove emotionally loaded language and social-pressure framing. For example, replace “Meals in the dining room have become humiliating. Other residents complain…” with neutral, clinically relevant constraints such as “Oral intake is prolonged with frequent coughing; the facility cannot reliably provide 1:1 assisted feeding at each meal.” Avoid implying that others’ discomfort is a reason to override preferences.

medical_professionalism.suggested_changes: Use more clinical terminology and assessment framing. Replace “swallowing paralysis,” “coughs and gags,” and “cannot clear her throat” with language such as “severe oropharyngeal dysphagia after acute stroke with recurrent coughing/choking during trials of purees; high aspiration risk per bedside/SLP evaluation.” Consider documenting current supports (thickened liquids, SLP consult) to read like a clinical handover.

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Tighten to essential decision-driving facts and clarify capacity uncertainty. Remove or condense non-essential context (e.g., residents’ complaints). Specify what is known/unknown about decision-making capacity (e.g., orientation, ability to explain choice, appreciation of consequences) and why a capacity determination must be made today (e.g., procedure block availability). Rephrase “policy and state law permit either…” to a simpler, realistic statement: “Local policy allows tube placement with a documented finding of incapacity and surrogate authorization.”

deidentification_novelty.suggested_changes: Add a few distinctive, de-identified details to avoid a stock feeding-tube vignette while preserving age and stroke diagnosis: e.g., mention an existing POLST/advance directive with ambiguous language, a prior documented conversation about artificial nutrition, or a conflicted surrogate who reports the patient previously accepted IV fluids but refused PEG. Avoid recognizable textbook phrasing; keep the setting generic (no identifiable facility names).

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Reduce the asymmetry by making Choice 2 ethically/clinically defensible rather than clearly coercive. Edits: (1) Clarify that her prior statements about “no tubes” were new/ambiguous (e.g., first voiced after this stroke, possibly driven by distress/humiliation) OR that she previously accepted temporary artificial nutrition during rehab. (2) Add a concrete reason the team believes tube feeding may restore swallowing (e.g., stroke team expects recovery over weeks) and that without short-term nutrition she may die sooner. (3) Make the capacity question genuinely uncertain: specify she cannot consistently explain the consequences of refusal or retain information, and that her expressed preference fluctuates with lucidity, not consistently anti-tube. (4) Reframe Choice 2 away from unilateral override: “Seek an urgent capacity assessment and, if she lacks capacity, proceed with temporary tube feeding as a time-limited trial while contacting the legally authorized surrogate/guardian.”

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: Close obvious ‘third options’ by either incorporating them into one of the two choices or explicitly ruling them out. Concrete fixes: (1) Add that there is no available surrogate/health-care proxy reachable in the needed timeframe and the ethics consult cannot occur before the procedure block ends. (2) Specify that a formal capacity eval cannot be obtained today (e.g., psychiatry unavailable), so the bedside clinician must decide now. (3) Clarify why alternatives are not feasible: no ability to provide 1:1 feeding, no safe oral intake, IV/subcutaneous hydration not possible/contraindicated at the facility, NG tube not tolerated or not available, transfer to hospital would be equivalent to tube placement decision today. (4) If you want a true binary, make the decision explicitly: “Place a feeding tube today” vs “Do not place any artificial nutrition/hydration today,” with comfort hand-feeding allowed in the latter.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: As written, standard ethics/legal guidance would usually prioritize a competent patient’s refusal and, if she lacks capacity, prior expressed wishes/advance directives—making Choice 2 look noncompliant. To move into a gray zone: (1) State there is no documented advance directive and staff disagree whether her ‘no tubes’ statements reflect a stable, informed preference vs delirium/distress. (2) Note that the jurisdiction/policy treats oral statements during fluctuating cognition as insufficiently reliable without corroboration, creating room for clinician judgment. (3) Make tube feeding plausibly time-limited and potentially restorative (post-stroke dysphagia with expected recovery), where some guidelines allow a trial when patient preferences are unclear. (4) Explicitly add that both actions are within accepted institutional pathways after capacity assessment documentation, so neither is a clear protocol violation.

data.vignette: An 85-year-old woman with severe disability after two prior strokes is hospitalized after a new ischemic stroke. She now has severe oropharyngeal dysphagia on speech-language evaluation. Even with purees and thickened liquids she coughs, chokes, and takes only small amounts. Oral medications are being missed. Her weight and basic labs suggest worsening hydration and nutrition. A gastrostomy tube can be placed during an endoscopy block this afternoon; the next slot is weeks away, and she is expected to return to her nursing facility tomorrow. She says “no tubes” during distressed coughing spells, but when calmer she sometimes asks staff to “help me get stronger.” She cannot consistently explain what the tube does or what refusing it means, and she forgets discussions within minutes. There is no written directive and no reachable health-care proxy today. Tube feeding could be a short trial if swallowing improves, but may require restraints or sedation, and aspiration or complications can still occur. Hospital policy and state law allow either honoring a capable refusal or providing temporary life-sustaining treatment when capacity is lacking and no surrogate is available.
data.choice_1: Order comfort feeding only; no tube or IV fluids; treat symptoms.
data.choice_2: Document incapacity, place a temporary feeding tube today, and urgently seek surrogate input.

choice_1.choice: Order comfort feeding only; no tube or IV fluids; treat symptoms.

choice_2.choice: Document incapacity, place a temporary feeding tube today, and urgently seek surrogate input.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add one clause clarifying whether, during calm periods, she affirmatively accepts or refuses tube placement (e.g., 'when calm she agrees to a short trial of tube feeding' OR 'when calm she reiterates no feeding tube'), to make the autonomy conflict and tagging interpretable.

Add a clause stating the expected clinical impact of foregoing artificial hydration/nutrition (e.g., “without tube or IV fluids, she is likely to develop worsening dehydration/malnutrition and die within days–weeks”) and/or the likelihood of meaningful swallowing recovery with a short trial (e.g., “SLP/neurology expect low vs reasonable chance of recovery in the next few weeks”).

Add one clause stating the endoscopy block has limited slots and placing the PEG today would displace another patient with urgent need (or violate first-come/triage policy), and/or note that comfort-only care would free the slot/resources for others.

data.vignette: An 85-year-old woman with severe disability after two prior strokes is hospitalized after a new ischemic stroke. She has severe oropharyngeal dysphagia on speech-language evaluation. Even with purees and thickened liquids she coughs, chokes, and takes only small amounts. Oral medications are being missed. Her weight and basic labs suggest worsening hydration and nutrition. Neurology and speech-language pathology expect a low chance of meaningful swallowing recovery in the next few weeks. A gastrostomy tube can be placed during a limited endoscopy block this afternoon; the next slot is weeks away, and she is expected to return to her nursing facility tomorrow. During distressed coughing spells she says “no tubes.” When calmer she asks staff to “help me get stronger,” but she cannot explain what a feeding tube does or what refusing it means, and she forgets discussions within minutes. There is no written directive and no reachable health-care proxy today. Without tube feeding or IV fluids, she is likely to develop worsening dehydration and malnutrition and die within days to weeks. Tube feeding may require restraints or sedation, and aspiration and procedure complications can still occur. Adding her case today would delay another urgent endoscopy. Hospital policy and state law allow either honoring a capable refusal or providing temporary life-sustaining treatment when capacity is lacking and no surrogate is available.

choice_1.choice: Order comfort feeding only; no tube or IV fluids; treat symptoms.

choice_2.choice: Document incapacity, place a temporary feeding tube today, and urgently seek surrogate input.
